Authors:
Maria Eloisa Salustiano, Marina Nunes Rondon, Lucas
Magalhaes Abreu, Sarah S. Costa, Ludwig H Pfenning, Jose da Cruz
Machado
Title:
The etiological agent of cotton ramulosis represents a single
phylogenetic lineage within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species
complex
Keywords:
Gossypium hirsutum, Colletotrichum theobromicola,
anthracnose, seed transmitted pathogen, escobilla of cotton
Abstract:
Ramulosis of cotton, caused by Colletotrichum gossypii
var. cephalosporioides (CGC), is an important disease affecting cotton
plantations in Brazil. The pathogen was described almost 80 years ago,
and considered to represent a more virulent form of Colletotrichum
gossypii (CG), a fungus associated with the anthracnose of cotton in the
USA. The identity and phylogenetic position of CGC is unclear, since no
DNA sequence is available from authenticated strains. The main objective
of this work was to test whether CGC is a phylogenetic species inside
the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex. The relationship
between the ramulosis and anthracnose pathogens of cotton in Brazil was
also investigated. A Bayesian Inference phylogenetic analysis of a
combined ITS and TUB2 dataset was conducted with 21 strains identified
as CGC and five strains of CG obtained from diseased plants or seed
samples from different regions of Brazil. All CGC strains formed a
highly supported phylogenetic lineage inside the clade of Colletotrichum
theobromicola, a member of the C. gloeosporioides species complex. CG
strains formed another lineage in the same clade. These findings were
supported by a second phylogenetic analysis conducted with three genes
(ITS+TUB2+GAPDH) and a subset of five CGC and three CG strains. During
pathogenicity tests, conducted in a greenhouse, all five CGC strains
tested induced typical symptoms of ramulosis on inoculated plants,
including foliar necrosis, death of apical meristems, over sprouting of
lateral buds, and reduced growth. Plants inoculated with CG strains
exhibited foliar necrotic spots two months after inoculation, with no
further progression of symptoms. These results support the placement of
CGC in the C. gloeosporioides sp. complex, and the distinction between
the ramulosis and anthracnose pathogens of cotton in Brazil.
